result.markdown: --- title: "Proto music: Credible signaling vs. social bonding" author: name: "Ed Hagen" affiliation: - name: Department of Anthropology, Washington State University department: Department of Anthropology date: "2025-05-28" draft: false image: gibbon.jpg categories: - slides description: "Talk for the Evolution of Music Workshop at the Santa Fe Institute, May 28, 2025" format: clean-revealjs: footer: "[ðŸ›– Home](/index.qmd)" css: /styles.css center: true embed-resources: false csl: apa.csl bibliography: references.bib --- ## Explicandum: [proto]{.fg style="--col: red"}-music The evolution in the human lineage of [vocalizations]{.alert} that are: :::{.center-h} * Loud * Synchronized * Variable ::: ## The social bonding hypothesis * Primate group cohesion putatively requires grooming * Grooming time putatively increases with group size * Large human groups required a more efficient "bonding" mechanism * Language/gossip, music, dance, and laughter evolved to replace grooming as the mechanism ## Against grooming as social bonding Dunbar's original data ![](dunbar_untransformed.svg) ## Against grooming as social bonding Dunbar's original data ![](dunbar_log.svg) ## Against grooming as social bonding Dunbar's original data ![](dunbar_substrate.svg) @grueter2013 ## The social bonding hypothesis ::: {.incremental} * In primates, group cohesion putatively requires grooming * Grooming time increases with group size * Large human groups required a more efficient "bonding" mechanism * Language/gossip, music, dance, and laughter evolved to replace grooming as the mechanism ::: ## Against music as social bonding Natural selection is an optimizing process ![](Dunbar.png){fig-align="center"} Figure modified from @tarr2014, my annotations in red. ## Against music as social bonding Natural selection is an optimizing process ![](socialbonding.png){fig-align="center"} Figure modified from @savage2021, my annotations in red. ## Against social bonding Effects are not (necessarily) functions * Singing and dancing might (or might not) increase warm feelings, but that is weak evidence that these evolved to do so * Petting animals reduces anxiety [@shiloh2003], but petting animals did not evolve to reduce anxiety ## "Social bonding" probably is explained by: :::{.center-h} * Mutual interest (e.g., predator defense) * Interdependence (e.g., sexual division of labor) * Kinship * Social exchange ::: ## The signaling hypothesis ## Signals These evolved to reveal signalers' [private information]{.alert} that elicits responses in receivers that [benefit]{.alert} signalers and (when not deceptive) receivers ## Signals are ubiquitous in nature :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} * within organisms * within species * between species ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![@van2019, @blount2023](monarch.jpg) ::: :::: ## Signals are ubiquitous in nature ![](signals.jpg){fig-align="center"} ## Common functions of animal vocal signals :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} * Mate attraction * Territorial advertisements * Alarm calls * Predator signaling ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} * Threats * Affiliation * Contact calls ::: :::: ## Animal coalitions The [costs of sociality]{.alert} often outweigh the benefits :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Costs of sociality * Resource/mate competition * Infectious disease * Infanticide (also reason for female coalitions) ::: ::: {.column width="50%} Compensating benefits * Predator defense * Territorial defense * Cooperative foraging * Cooperative parenting ::: :::: ## Coalitional signaling :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Signals * Territorial advertisements * Predator signaling * Threats * Mate attraction (rare) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Credibility * Existence * Number * Coordination/cooperativeness ::: :::: ## Human evolution: Timeline ![](miocene.png){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Late Miocene ![](loudcalls.png){fig-align="center"} @wich2002: Territoriality (resource defense)? ## Human evolution: Late Miocene ![](gibbon.jpg){fig-align="center"} ::: {.center} Gibbon duetting: monogamous pairs produce highly synchronized song-like calls ::: ## Human evolution: Late Miocene ![](mmc3.2.mov){fig-align="center" height="500"} Chimpanzee drumming: [population-specific]{.alert} rhythms [@eleuteri2025] ## Human evolution: Late Miocene Composition and recursion enable tremendous [variation]{.alert}: * Chimpanzee call composition [@girard2025] * Bonobo call composition [@berthet2025] * Orangutan call recursion [@DeGregorio2025] ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![](pliocene.png){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Pliocene Predation pressure ![](predators1.svg){fig-align="center"} @hagen2022 ## Human evolution: Pliocene Predation pressure ![](predators2.svg){fig-align="center"} @hagen2022 ## Signaling adaptations to predation pressure ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![Signaling predator detection](predator-detection.jpg){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![Signaling chemical defense](Striped_Skunk.jpg){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![](mesocarnivores.jpg){fig-align="center"} Mesocarnivores: face badges signal [pugnacity]{.alert} [@newman2005] ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![Baboon threat signal](baboon.jpeg){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Pliocene Predation threat: signaling and coalitional defense {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rienIm7EqO4 width="1120" height="500" start="60" >}} ## Human evolution: Pleistocene ![](pleistocene.png) ## Cooperative hunting ## Human evolution: Pleistocene ![](canids.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} @macdonald2019 ## Credible signaling of coalition quality {{< video https://youtu.be/MB3tZXg729M width="1100" height="619" start="23" >}} ## Credible signaling of coalition quality Feasting and alliances ![](thefeast.small.mov){fig-align="center" height="500"} ## Signaling summary Loud coordinated vocal chorusing likely has deep roots in human evolution :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} Miocene ape [loud]{.alert} calls * Territoriality * Contact calls * [Combinatorial?: variation]{.alert} ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} Pliocene hominin coalitions * Territoriality * Predator deterrence (detection) * [Coordinated?: pugnacity]{.alert} ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} Pleistocene *Homo* coalitions * Territoriality * War songs & dances * [Feasting & alliances: coalition quality]{.alert} ::: :::: ## Possible [signaling]{.alert} contributions to social bonding within and between groups Group-specfic songs and dances provide [information]{.alert} on :::{.center-h} * Identity * Commitment * Common knowledge ::: ## Vocalizations evolved to provide [valuable information]{.alert} (ultimate level), not to increase neurotransmiter levels (proximate level) ## Questions? ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.center-h} ![](qrcode.svg) These slides ::: ##     function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
